head.title: Giants Trace Success to Their Happy New Home

hedline.hl1: Giants Trace Success to Their Happy New Home

abstract.p: San Francisco Giants discuss their successful season and outlook for National League division series against New York Mets (M)

block.p: Ellis Burks, the 36-year-old right fielder, was among the first players in the Giants' clubhouse today, arriving early to enjoy the perks of what may be the strongest home-stadium advantage in Major League Baseball.

Ellis Burks, the 36-year-old right fielder, was among the first players in the Giants' clubhouse today, arriving early to enjoy the perks of what may be the strongest home-stadium advantage in Major League Baseball.

Never mind batting practice or the Mets' scouting report; Burks came to Pacific Bell Park to take a swim. Specifically, to jump in the Giants' high-tech training pool and loosen his oft-injured knees.
Asked to contrast the bejeweling Pacific Bell Park and the bedeviling Candlestick Park, Burks laughed as though he had to choose between arthritis and a rejuvenated career.

''We just had a tub at Candlestick, a tin tub,'' Burks said. ''It's just night and day. You don't have the cold weather. The winds are not nearly as strong. We've got state-of-the-art facilities. And there's something about playing at home in front of a sellout crowd every night that gets you going. We weren't used to that. It's more of a baseball atmosphere here. Everything is right on top of you. It's the difference between playing in front of 45,000 fans and 15,000.''

The Giants view their new stadium as their trump card when dealing with the Mets in the three-of-five-game division series that begins Wednesday. The Giants say it was no coincidence that team revenues more than doubled to $135 million and huge dividends were reaped on the field in their first season at Pacific Bell.

''It has been the single biggest factor in our success this year,'' said Peter Magowan, the Giants' president. ''In the past, we'd come back from a road trip against, say, the Expos and start a homestand on a Wednesday night and 12,000 people would be here for us. It was demoralizing at times. Here, the energy from the crowd is obvious every night.''
First baseman J. T. Snow said: ''It's like going to work in a nice office. You're just in a little better mood when you get here.''

The Giants' 55-26 home record was their best since 1962, and tied the Mets for tops in the majors. And the Giants point to a four-game sweep of the Mets here in May as a crucial moment in making this park miserable for visiting teams. Jeff Kent, the ex-Met, led the assault, hitting three home runs in the series, including a three-run homer in the 11th inning for an 8-5 victory on May 3.

''That was an important game for the psychology of this franchise,'' said Larry Baer, the team's executive vice president. ''That series and that game gave us a lot of confidence that we could play well in our new ballpark.''

The Giants had lost their first six games at Pacific Bell and were 10-13, five games behind the division-leading Arizona Diamondbacks. But they shaped up and won the N.L. West by 11 games over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

''We hope they never do figure it out,'' Kent said, referring to the Mets' woes here. ''What has been a benefit for us is the fact that this is a quality, beautiful, odd-shaped ballpark, and it doesn't bug us. I think a lot of players come in here and get wrapped up in its beauty and quirky corners in right field.
''It looks like a short porch out there, too, so pitchers might be intimidated by that a bit. But this is a very fair ballpark.''
Visiting teams can be fooled into thinking Pacific Bell is a power hitter's paradise like Enron Field in Houston or Coors Field in Denver. But the Giants say that pitching and defense are rewarded.

''When teams come in here, they think they're going to hit a lot of home runs and score a lot,'' Snow said, ''but it's not really like that. This park can affect their minds like that, which can help us.''

The power alleys measure 404 feet to left-center field and 421 to right center. Although it is only 309 feet down the right-field line, a home run needs to carry over a 25-foot wall. The winds are gentle, too, usually blowing in from right center and out to left center.
